item.title: tsylor
item.author: michael@michaelneuper.com (Aditya Kumar Singh)
item.description:
Taylor theorem

Introductions

A sequence of real numbers is a function from the set of natural numbers to the set of real numbers. $$ f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{R} $$

Example

  • $$a_{n}=\frac{1}{n}$$
  • $$a_{n}=n$$

Increasing and Decreasing sequence

A sequence ${a_{n}}$ is increasing if $$\forall_{n \in \mathbb{N}} ; a_{n + 1} > a_{n}$$ and the sequence is decreasing if $$\forall_{n \in \mathbb{N}} ; a_{n + 1} < a_{n}$$

Example

  • $$a_{n}=n$$ is a increasing sequence.
  • $$a_{n}=\frac{1}{n}$$ is a decreasing sequence.

Boundedness of sequence

A sequence ${a_{n}}$ is bounded above if $$\exists_{M \in \mathbb{R}}\forall_{n \in \mathbb{N}} ; a_{n} \le M$$ and the sequence ${a_{n}}$ is bounded below if $$\exists_{M \in \mathbb{R}}\forall_{n \in \mathbb{N}} ; a_{n} \ge M$$

lower extremal limit

$$\lim_{n \to \infty}\text{inf } a_{n} = \lim_{n \to \infty}(\text{inf }{k > n} a{n})$$

upper extremal limit

$$\lim_{n \to \infty}\text{sup } a_{n} = \lim_{n \to \infty}(\text{sup }{k > n} a{n})$$

Convergence of Sequence

Sequence converging to finite value

Let {$a_{n}$} be sequence. We say this has limit b if for each real number $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a natural number $N$ such that , for each natural number $n \ge N$, we have $|x_{n}- a| < \epsilon$ . $$\lim_{n \to \infty}a_{n}= b$$

Example

  • $$a_{n}=\frac{1}{n}; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n} = 0$$
  • $$a_{n}=\frac{(-1)^n}{n}; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n} = 0$$
  • $$a_{2m}=\frac{1}{m}, a_{2m + 1}= \frac{1}{2m}; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n} = 0$$
  • $$a_n=\frac{n}{n+1}; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n}=0$$
  • $$a_n=\sqrt[n]{p}; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n}=1$$

Sequence converging to infinite value

Let ${a_n}$ be sequence. We say this sequence is converging to infinite if for every real number M, there is a natural number N such that for every natural number $n \ge N$ , we have $a_{n} \gt M$.

$$\lim_{n \to \infty}a_{n}= \infty$$

Example

  • $$a_n=n; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n}=\infty$$
  • $$a_n={n^2}; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n}=\infty$$

Diverging Sequence

If sequence is not converging, we say it is diverging.

Example

  • $$a_n={(-1)^n}; \lim_{n \to \infty}{a_n}=\infty$$

Properties

  • $$ (\lim_{n \to \infty}a_{n}) \pm (\lim_{n \to \infty}b_{n}) = \lim_{n \to \infty}(a_{n} \pm b_{n}) $$
  • $$ (\lim_{n \to \infty}a_{n}) \cdot (\lim_{n \to \infty}b_{n}) = \lim_{n \to \infty}(a_{n} \cdot b_{n}) $$
  • $$ \lim_{n \to \infty}(c \cdot a_{n}) = c \cdot\lim_{n \to \infty}(a_{n}) $$
  • $$ (\lim_{n \to \infty}a_{n}) / (\lim_{n \to \infty}b_{n}) = \lim_{n \to \infty}(a_{n} / b_{n}) \text{ if } \lim_{n \to \infty}b_{n} \ne 0 $$

Difficult Question

Does following sequence converges ? If does, what is their limits ?

  1. $$a_{n} = \sqrt[4]{n^{4}+2n^{3}} - \sqrt[4]{n^{4}+n^{3}}$$

    • $$a_{n} = \sqrt[4]{n^{4}+2\sqrt{n}\cdot n^{3}} - \sqrt[4]{n^{4}+\sqrt{n}\cdot n^{3}}$$
    • $$a_{n} = \sqrt[4]{n^{4}+2n^{2}} - \sqrt[4]{n^{4}+n^{2}}$$

  2. $$a_{n}= \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+1}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+2}} + \cdots + \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+n}}$$

    • $$a_{n}= \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+1}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+2}} + \cdots + \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+k}} \text{for fixed } k \in \mathbb{N}.$$
    • $$a_{n}= \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+1^{2}}} + \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+2^{2}}} + \cdots + \frac{1}{\sqrt{n^{2}+n^{2}}}$$

  3. $$a_{n}= \sqrt[n]{\lambda_{1}^{n} + \lambda_{2}^{n} + \cdots + \lambda_{k}^{n}}$$ where $k \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\lambda_{i} > 0, i =1, 2, \cdots, k$

  4. $$a_{n}= sin(\pi\sqrt{a^{2}+n^{2}}), a > 0 $$

  5. $$a_{n}=n(\frac{\pi}{2}-arccos(\frac{1}{n}))$$
